entry.dc:title: Cardiomyopathies of obscure origin in Cali, Colombia. Clinical, etiologic, and laboratory aspects
entry.dc:creator: Araújo J.
entry.dc:description: Forty-one patients with heart diseases of unknown etiology seen in Cali, Colombia, were studied clinically, pathologically, and with laboratory procedures, which included electrocardiograms, chest x-ray films, and, in some instances, cardiac catheterization. Pathologically, three groups were defined. Group I (33 patients) was characterized by degenerative lesions of the cardiac muscle; 12 cases were associated with other conditions such as the sickle cell trait, hyperthyroidism, the postpartum state, and alcoholism. Group II (4 patients) showed predominant endomyocardial fibrosis. Group III consisted of 4 patients with myocarditis. With the exception of one case of endomyocardial fibrosis that suggested rheumatic valvular disease, the clinical features among the three groups were similar. Etiologic possibilities such as Chagas' disease malnutrition, sickle cell abnormality, anemia, and intestinal parasites are discussed. © 1970.

entry.dc:title: Potentiation by chronic methyldopa treatment of the vascular resistance responses to central sympathetic stimulation and to exogenous norepinephrine
entry.dc:creator: Gómez B.
entry.dc:description: The effects of chronic administration of alphamethyldopa (MDo) on the vascular resistance responses to central electrical stimulation and to exogenous i. a. norepinephrine (NE) were studied in the constant flow pump-perfused hindquarters of untreated and MDo-pretreated cats. These responses were found to be significantly greater in the latter group. © 1970.

entry.dc:title: Utilization of exogenous urea nitrogen in malnourished adults
entry.dc:creator: Tripathy K.
entry.dc:description: The utilization of exogenous urea as a nitrogen source was studied in 10 malnourished adults. Urea administration induced a significant positive nitrogen balance in all cases. In three subjects increasing doses of urea nitrogen induced a corresponding rise in positive nitrogen balance. Neomycin administration produced a slight decrease in urea nitrogen retention, apparently due to an increased fecal nitrogen loss during neomycin induced diarrhea. An increased supply of dietary protein as well as an improved nutritional status were shown to abolish the need for utilization of urea nitrogen. Intravenous urea administration in two subjects demonstrated similar effects to those obtained through oral route of administration. © 1970.

affiliation.affilname: Tulane University School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine

entry.dc:title: Arteritis of the aorta and its major branches
entry.dc:creator: Muñoz N.
entry.dc:description: The clinical and necropsy features are described in 7 patients with arteritis of the aorta and its major branches. Five had foci of coagulative necrosis surrounded by fibroblasts, mononuclear leukocytes, and occasional giant cells in the aorta. The relation of these lesions to rheumatoid nodules is discussed. The similarity of some of these lesions to those produced in dogs by the nematode, Spirocerca lupi, and those produced in humans by a nematode of the suborder, Strongyllata, is also discussed. © 1970.

entry.dc:title: The thermal decomposition of β-hydroxy ketones
entry.dc:creator: Yates B.
entry.dc:description: β-Hydroxy ketones decompose thermally to mixtures of aldehydes and ketones in a reaction that is the reverse of the aldol condensation. A study has been carried out of the kinetics of the thermal decomposition of some β-hydroxy ketones in xylene solution. The results indicate that the reaction is unimolecular and involves a cyclic transition state. Comparison of the rates of decomposition of the different β-hydroxy ketones indicates that little charge separation is obtained during the breaking of the carbon-carbon bond in the transition state.

entry.dc:title: Protein-calorie malnutrition in Candelaria, Colombia I. Prevalence; social and demographic causal factors
entry.dc:creator: Wray J.

entry.dc:title: A new assay for phage hydroxymethylases and its use in Bacillus subtilis transfection
entry.dc:creator: Alegria A.
entry.dc:description: The enzymatic synthesis of 5-hydroxymethyl-5′-deoxyuridylic acid, which replaces thymidylic acid in the deoxyribonucleic acid of certain bacteriophages infecting Bacillus subtilis, is reversible. This property can be utilized in measuring the enzyme that catalyzes the reaction. A mononucleotide labeled with radioactive formaldehyde is first prepared enzymatically. To assay the enzyme, the release of formaldehyde from this radioactive substrate is then determined. The method described is highly sensitive, simple, and reproducible and allows the easy detection of the low enzyme levels present in competent cells infected with purified phage deoxyribonucleic acid. The 5′-deoxycytidylic acid hydroxymethylase induced in Escherichia coli by T2 bacteriophage also catalyzes a reversible reaction and can be assayed in a similar way. However, the deoxyuridylic acid and the deoxycytidylic acid phage-induced hydroxymethylases act only on their respective substrate. Some preliminary data on the induction of deoxycytidylic acid hydroxymethylase by phage-SP82 deoxyribonucleic acid in B. subtilis competent cells are presented.

entry.dc:title: Kinetics of the chlorination of mercuric chloride in acetone at a solid surface
entry.dc:creator: Hellemans L.
entry.dc:description: Although potassium chloride is insoluble in acetone, it will dissolve in a mercury(II) chloride solution through formation of charged complexes. The rate of this heterogeneous reaction has been followed conductometrically at 25°. An attempt was made to calculate the area for sifted fractions of the potassium salt. It has been shown that in the concentration range up to 2 × 10 -3 M HgCl 2, the only product is potassium trichloromercurate, formed by means of an adsorption process. The adsorption constant K is (2.1 ± 0.4) × 10 2l. mol -1, and the product with the rate constant of complexation k 2K is (6.19 ± 0.30) × 10 -2 min -1 cm -2.

entry.dc:title: The relationship of sickle cell trait to variations in blood pressure
entry.dc:creator: Rossi-Espagnet A.
entry.dc:description: Rossi-Espagnet, A., K. W. Newell, R. MacLennan, J. B. Mathison (Division of Epidemiology, Tulane University, New Orleans, La.) and S. P. H. Mandel (Department of Community Medidne, University of Vermont, Burlington, Ve.). The relationship of sickle cell trait to variations in blood pressure. Amer. J. Epid., 1968, 88: 33 44.-The investigation that forms the object of this paper is related to the known fact that Negroes exhibit higher blood pressures and higher and earlier mortality due to hypertensive heart disease and cerebrovascular accidents than non-Negroes. The hypothesis of a possible association between sickle cell trait and variations of blood pressure was tested in two Negro populations of Colombia, South America in an attempt to find a possible explanation for the differences mentioned above. The sickle cell trait is widely distributed in the Negro race and relatively uncommon among non-Negroes, and certain types of renal damage have been found to be associated with this. A total of 2, 155 persons of both sexes aged 20 years or more were examined in defined sections of two Columbian towns at sea level and at 1, 000 m of altitude, respectively. Blood pressure values were obtained by single casual measurements using mercury manometers. The results of the study indicated that there were no significant differences in either systolic or diastolic blood pressures of Negroes who had positive sickle cell slide tests as compared with Negroes who had negative sickle cell slide tests. © 1968, by The Johns Hopkins University.

entry.dc:title: Differential absorption of the heme and globin moieties of hemoglobin
entry.dc:creator: Tripathy K.
entry.prism:publicationName: The American Journal of Digestive Diseases
entry.dc:description: Studies were performed in 4 healthy men to determine the intestinal absorption and fecal excretion of the heme and the protein moieties of hemoglobin when hemoglobin was given orally in large amounts. The relatively higher absorption of the protein moiety of hemoglobin was confirmed by a proportionate increase in urinary nitrogen. These observations indicate that the role of blood loss in the pathogenesis of protein malnutrition in patients with hookworm disease is minimal. © 1967 Hoeber Medical Division • Harper & Row, Publishers, Incorporated.

entry.dc:title: The fine structure of human chorionic villi and placental transfer of iron in late pregnancy
entry.dc:creator: Salazar H.
entry.prism:publicationName: American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology
entry.dc:description: A description and functional interpretation of the principal morphologic characteristics of human chorionic villi in term placentas are presented. Electron microscopic observations and histochemical data reveal the occurrence of ferritin and hydrous ferric oxide deposits located exclusively on the trophoblastic basement membrane of some villi. This is interpreted as a blockage in the normal transfer of iron across the placental barrier of some chorionic villi in which the basement membrane functions as a selective filter. © 1967.

affiliation.affilname: Hospital General del Centro Médico Nacional

entry.dc:title: Radium isotope accumulation in animal thyroids
entry.dc:creator: Van Middlesworth L.
entry.dc:description: Uranium and thorium daughters are ten times more concentrated in thyroids from some bovine animals than in the teeth of the same animals. These radioactive isotopes are believed to be from natural sources, but their resulting annual dosage of thyroid radiation has exceeded that from iodine-131 fallout.

affiliation.affilname: University of Tennessee Health Science Center

entry.dc:title: Superconductivity of thorium and uranium
entry.dc:creator: Gordon J.
entry.dc:description: The low-temperature susceptibility and specific heat of thorium and uranium have been measured. It is found that thorium becomes a superconductor at Tc=(1.374±0.001)°K, and has a value of Ces(Tc)γTc=2.42, in good agreement with BCS theory. (Here Ces is the superconducting electronic specific heat, and γ is the temperature coefficient of the normal electronic specific heat.) The γ and ΘD for thorium were found to be (4.31±0.05) mJ/mole deg2 and (163.3±0.7)°K, respectively. Both uranium samples appeared to undergo superconducting transitions when observed magnetically, yet both exhibited only normal-state behavior in their specific heat. Hence it seems likely that the apparent superconductivity of alpha uranium is not characteristic of the bulk metal. The γ and ΘD of the purer uranium sample were found to be (10.03±0.02) mJ/mole deg2 and (207±1) °K, respectively. © 1966 The American Physical Society.

entry.dc:title: Primary ocular sporotrichosis
entry.dc:creator: Raúl Alvarez G.

entry.dc:title: Uterine behavior in abruptio placentae. I. Contraction patterns and their reactivity to oxytocin
entry.dc:creator: Cobo E.
entry.prism:publicationName: American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology
entry.dc:description: 1. 1. Twenty-four cases of severe abruptio placentae were studied using the method of amniotic fluid pressure recording. 2. 2. Based on differences in tonus, frequency, and pharmacological reactivity to oxytocin, two distinct patterns of uterine motility are described. 3. 3. Uterine tonus and contraction frequency appear to be good indicators of the functional status of uterine muscle in abruptio. Physiopathological significance of these findings is discussed. 4. 4. There seems to be no relationship between the type of uterine pattern and the clinical aspects of the condition. © 1965.

entry.dc:title: A case of ocular onchocerciasis in Colombia
entry.dc:creator: Assis-Masri G.
entry.prism:publicationName: Transactions of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene

entry.dc:title: Folate and B12 serum levels in premature infants. With a note on milk folate
entry.dc:creator: Ghitis J.

entry.dc:title: Neurohypophyseal hormone release in the human. I. Experimental study during pregnancy
entry.dc:creator: Cobo E.
entry.prism:publicationName: American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology
entry.dc:description: An experimental study of simultaneous oxytocic and antidiuretic activities, induced by baby's suckling, mammary duct dilatation, nicotine, and hypertonic saline during human pregnancy, is presented. The criteria to infer oxytocic and antidiuretic actions by measuring uterine activity, free water clearance, and urinary osmolality are discussed. Results reported in this paper demonstrate the independence of oxytocic and antidiuretic activities, within the limits of physiological conditions, and suggest the possibility of a selective release of oxytocin and vasopressin in human pregnancy. © 1965.

entry.dc:title: Uterine hypercontractility in toxemia of pregnancy. I. Its prolonged therapeutic control
entry.dc:creator: Cobo E.
entry.prism:publicationName: American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology
entry.dc:description: 1. 1. A report of a study of uterine contractility in toxemia of pregnancy is presented. 2. 2. In all cases studied uterine hypercontractility was found, confirming the findings reported by other authors. 3. 3. A deep depressing or regulating effect of the uterine hypercontractility, produced by the medical treatment of the toxemia of pregnancy, is described. The treatment was based upon absolute bed rest, low-salt diet, fluid balance, sedation, magnesium sulfate, diuretics, and hypotensives. © 1964.

entry.dc:title: The prophylactic and therapeutic use of bendroflumethiazide in pregnancy
entry.dc:creator: Cuadros A.
entry.prism:publicationName: American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology

entry.dc:title: Diethylene glycol distearate embedding and ultramicrotome sectioning for light microscopy
entry.dc:creator: Salazar H.
entry.dc:description: Diethylene glycol distearate can be used as an embedding medium for light microscopy. Two infiltration changes of about 6 hr each in the melted wax (melting point 47-52 C) are required before the final embedding which is done in 00 gelatin capsules for sectioning in the ultramicrotome by the procedure used in electron microscopy. Serial sections 1-2 μ thick can be cut without difficulty. No cooling devices are necessary for trimming and sectioning at laboratory temperature. Sections rarely become detached from the slides. The staining characteristics of the tissues are the same as when embedded in paraffin. For fluorescence microscopy, essentially the same procedure is followed. Tissues are not distorted and the intracellular structures are well preserved. © 1964 Informa UK Ltd All rights reserved: reproduction in whole or part not permitted.

affiliation.affilname: Washington University in St. Louis, School of Medicine

entry.dc:title: Pathology of heart diseases of undetermined etiology which occur in Cali, Colombia
entry.dc:creator: Correa P.
entry.dc:description: Heart disease of unknown etiology is a common cause of death in Cali. Clinical characteristics are described in 28 cases; pathologic patterns found at autopsy allowed the definition of two distinct pathologic types and a third type which consisted of miscellaneous findings grouped together for purposes of discussion. Type I is characterized by the presence of focal progressive myocardial lysis with or without mural thrombosis and endocardial fibrosis. Type II is characterized by endocardial fibrosis with or without mural thrombosis and no myocardial lysis. Type III is a heterogeneous group characterized by mural thrombosis, hypertrophy, and dilation. The similarities of our cases to, and differences from, other cases reported are discussed, and a brief review of the etiological agents considered is made. © 1963.

entry.dc:title: Capillary samples for hemoglobin electrophoresis
entry.dc:creator: Ghitis J.

entry.dc:title: Tranquilizing drugs and pregnancy tests in male batrachia
entry.dc:creator: Bueno M.
entry.dc:description: The reactions for the diagnosis of pregnancy by the use of urine from patients who are receiving tranquilizing drugs of the phenothiazine group have given false positive results when performed in the North, American frog Rana pipiens. Such false positive reactions are not obtained when the South American toad Bufo arenarum is used.

entry.dc:title: Acute benign erythroblastopenia possibly chloramphenicol induced
entry.dc:creator: Ghitis J.
entry.dc:description: An account is given of 2 patients not suffering from a hemolytic disease who developed acute erythroblastopenia with uneventful recovery. Chloramphenicol may have been involved in the process. © 1962 The C. V. Mosby Company.

entry.dc:title: Parasitological surveys in Cali, Departamento del Valle, Colombia VI. Strongyloidiasis in Barrio Siloé, Cali, Colombia
entry.dc:creator: Carroll Faust E.
entry.prism:publicationName: Transactions of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene
entry.dc:description: 1. 1) In connexion with a continuing parasitological survey of a representative sampling of the population in ward Siloé, Cali, Colombia, conducted as part of an epidemiological study of this economically poor community, a special segment of the programme has been concerned with Strongyloides stercoralis infection. This investigation included 92 families comprising 982 persons. Freshly-passed faecal specimens were examined macroscopically and microscopically for intestinal parasites, employing unstained and iodine-stained direct faecal films supplemented by zinc sulphate concentration preparations. 2. 2) A total of 2974 stools were examined from November, 1956, through April, 1959. One hundred and thirty-seven (14 per cent.) of the 982 individuals were found positive for Strongyloides. One hundred and six were first diagnosed from the first specimen submitted, 20 were first diagnosed from the second specimen, seven from the third sample, and four from the fourth. Subsequent samples provided no additional first positives. 3. 3) The zinc sulphate centrifugal floation technique proved to be 50 per cent. more efficient than the double cover-glass direct films in discovering Strongyloides larvae. 4. 4) One or more persons in each of 62 of the 92 families were found to be infected, by the techniques employed. The number of positive persons per family varied from one to nine. 5. 5) Appreciable infection (4.8 per cent.) occurred before 5 years of age, after which time the incidence rate rose rapidly during the next quinquennium, maintained this level for three decades, rose again in the fourth decade, remained high in the males and rapidly declined in the females. The incidence per cent. was consistently higher in the males than in the females after the first 5-year period. 6. 6) Environmental conditions and low-grade personal hygiene are conducive to exposure to infective-stage Strongyloides on the moist dirt floors of the houses of the community. Autoinfection may play a significant role in maintaining the infection once it has become established. 7. 7) There is no evidence that strongyloidiasis in ward Siloé is a severe debilitating disease; rather it appears to be a chronic parasitosis which is fairly well tolerated. © 1960.

entry.dc:title: An experiment on osmotic flow
entry.dc:creator: Borrero L.

entry.dc:title: Survey for sero-immunity to poliomyelitis in Peru and Colombia: With comments on the changing pattern of occurrence of poliomyelitis in tropical areas
entry.dc:creator: Gelfand H.
